Now I'm a target, but all I’ve ever wanted is for people to see the truth hiding behind their scores.

variants: Everyone found out how their scores got made. It got loud for a while.

I grew up thinking compliance was everything, but when I leaked that code, I realized how hollow it all is.

People who never left their block are suddenly organizers, wiring up networks that the Council can’t touch.
I saw the Council’s memos—panicked, grasping at power, desperate to stop the bleeding by switching off automation in neighborhoods where unrest was loudest.
Manual oversight means officers improvise. Some abuse it, others quietly help organize resistance.
I’ve got friends on both sides, and they admit: this system only worked because nobody looked too closely before.
I never hid that I think compliance is just the city’s leash on all of us. Now that leash is fraying.
The best part? Those old barriers—status, score, background—they mean less now than ever.
Stenograd feels dangerous, but more alive than it’s been in years.
